problem_text: This is a GeomVerse problem. If the adjacent angles CAB and CAD are complementary, the arc length of the FCE sector is 23.13 and the angle FCE is vertical to BCA, compute the degree of the CBA angle. Assume $\pi=3.14$. Round computations to 2 decimal places.
code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import matplotlib.patches as patches
import numpy as np

# Coordinates
A = (34.23, 34.23)
B = (34.23, 16204.48)
C = (6190.59, 16948.7)
D = (5034.23, 34.23)
E = (27038.81, 19468.949999999997)
F = (13373.019999999999, 36682.240000000005)

# Create figure and axis
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 10))

# Draw the cyan triangle (A, B, C)
cyan_triangle = patches.Polygon([A, B, C], closed=True, color="cyan", alpha=0.6)
ax.add_patch(cyan_triangle)

# Draw the brown sector (C, E, F)
start_angle = np.degrees(np.arctan2(E[1] - C[1], E[0] - C[0]))
end_angle = np.degrees(np.arctan2(F[1] - C[1], F[0] - C[0]))

if start_angle > end_angle:
    end_angle += 360

arc = patches.Wedge(
    center=C,
    r=21,
    theta1=start_angle,
    theta2=end_angle,
    facecolor="brown",
    edgecolor="black",
    alpha=0.6
)
ax.add_patch(arc)

# Draw the line AD
ax.plot([A[0], D[0]], [A[1], D[1]], color='black', alpha=0.6)

# Draw angle markers
def draw_angle_marker(ax, center, p1, p2, radius, angle_text, color="gray", alpha=0.8):
    '''Draws an angle marker and label.'''
    angle1 = np.arctan2(p1[1] - center[1], p1[0] - center[0])
    angle2 = np.arctan2(p2[1] - center[1], p2[0] - center[0])
    
    if angle2 < angle1:
        angle2 += 2 * np.pi

    theta = np.linspace(angle1, angle2, 100)
    x = center[0] + radius * np.cos(theta)
    y = center[1] + radius * np.sin(theta)
    ax.fill(x, y, color=color, alpha=alpha)

    # Add angle text
    mid_angle = (angle1 + angle2) / 2
    text_x = center[0] + (radius + 1) * np.cos(mid_angle)
    text_y = center[1] + (radius + 1) * np.sin(mid_angle)
    ax.text(text_x, text_y, angle_text, fontsize=14, ha="center", va="center")

draw_angle_marker(ax, B, A, C, radius=1, angle_text=r"$?$")
draw_angle_marker(ax, A, D, C, radius=1, angle_text=r"$70^circ$")

# Add labels
ax.text(A[0], A[1], "A", fontsize=16, ha="right", va="top")
ax.text(B[0], B[1], "B", fontsize=16, ha="right", va="bottom")
ax.text(C[0], C[1], "C", fontsize=16, ha="left", va="top")
ax.text(D[0], D[1], "D", fontsize=16, ha="right", va="top")
ax.text(E[0], E[1], "E", fontsize=16, ha="left", va="bottom")
ax.text(F[0], F[1], "F", fontsize=16, ha="left", va="bottom")

# -- LENGTH ANNOTATION -- #
ax.text((B[0] + C[0]) / 2, (B[1] + C[1]) / 2, "21", fontsize=16, ha="left", va="center")

# Configure the plot
ax.set_xlim(-4965.77, 30034.23)
ax.set_ylim(-4965.77, 40034.23)
ax.set_aspect("equal")
ax.axis("off")

# Show the plot
plt.show()

ext_info.cot: The sum of the degrees of an angle and its complementary angle is 90. The CAB angle has a complementary angle with degree 70 so the degree of the CAB angle is 90 - 70 = 20. The CF radius of the FCE sector is 21 and the arc length is 23.13. So the FCE angle can be computed as $\frac{ArcLength}{2 \pi r} * 360 = \frac{23.13}{2 \pi * 21} * 360 = \frac{23.13}{131.88} * 360 = 0.18 * 360 = 64.8$. The angle BCA is vertical to the angle FCE so the degree of the BCA angle = 64.8. The degrees of the BCA and the CAB angles of the ABC triangle are 64.8 and 20, so the degree of the CBA angle $= 180 - 64.8 - 20 = 95.2$. Therefore the final answer is 95.2.
